description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Daily India Report-- Data detailed on Materials Research have been presented. Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the National Institute of Technology Calicut,“ In this work, Mg-Ca alloy was chemically treated with acetic acid and its effects on degradation behaviour were studied...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Daily India
Report -- Data detailed on Materials Research have been presented. According
to news reporting out of Kerala, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated,
"Magnesium and its alloys are suitable candidates for developing biodegradable
metallic implants. However, the rapid degradation of these alloys in the
physiological environment is a major limitation for such applications."

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the National
Institute of Technology Calicut, "In this work, Mg-Ca alloy was chemically
treated with acetic acid and its effects on degradation behaviour were studied
using simulated body fluid (SBF). The surface morphology and composition of
the acid pickled samples were investigated using a scanning electron
microscope (SEM) and infrared spectroscopy (IR). The degradation rate was
analysed by conducting potentiodynamic polarization (PDP) and immersion tests.
The results show that optimum acetic acid treatment improved the corrosion
resistance by acid etching and formation of magnesium acetate layer. The
treated samples also exhibited enhanced biomineralization and developed
calcium phosphate layer on the surfaces during immersion tests."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "It is proposed that
acetic acid pickling can be used as a reliable technique for surface
modification as well as for pre-treatment of magnesium alloys to make them
suitable for degradable metallic implant applications."

For more information on this research see: Tailoring biomineralization and
biodegradation of Mg-Ca alloy by acetic acid pickling. _Materials Research
Express_ , 2020;7(5):054002. _Materials Research Express_ can be contacted at:
Iop Publishing Ltd, Temple Circus, Temple Way, Bristol BS1 6BE, England.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting T. Hanas, National Institute of Technology Calicut, Dept. of
Mechanical Engineering, Calicut 673601, Kerala, India. Additional authors for
this research include S.A. Rahim and M.A. Joseph.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1088/2053-1591/ab8d5f>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Data from National Institute of Technology Calicut Illuminate Findings in Materials Research (Tailoring biomineralization and biodegradation of Mg-Ca alloy by acetic acid pickling): Materials Research
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Daily India Report -- Data detailed on Materials Research have been presented. According to news reporting out of Kerala, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated, “Magnesium and its alloys are suitable candidates for developing biodegradable metallic implants. However, the rapid degradation of these alloys in the physiological environment is a major limitation for such applications.”

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the National Institute of Technology Calicut, “In this work, Mg-Ca alloy was chemically treated with acetic acid and its effects on degradation behaviour were studied using simulated body fluid (SBF). The surface morphology and composition of the acid pickled samples were investigated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) and infrared spectroscopy (IR). The degradation rate was analysed by conducting potentiodynamic polarization (PDP) and immersion tests. The results show that optimum acetic acid treatment improved the corrosion resistance by acid etching and formation of magnesium acetate layer. The treated samples also exhibited enhanced biomineralization and developed calcium phosphate layer on the surfaces during immersion tests.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “It is proposed that acetic acid pickling can be used as a reliable technique for surface modification as well as for pre-treatment of magnesium alloys to make them suitable for degradable metallic implant applications.”

For more information on this research see: Tailoring biomineralization and biodegradation of Mg-Ca alloy by acetic acid pickling. Materials Research Express, 2020;7(5):054002. Materials Research Express can be contacted at: Iop Publishing Ltd, Temple Circus, Temple Way, Bristol BS1 6BE, England.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting T. Hanas, National Institute of Technology Calicut, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Calicut 673601, Kerala, India. Additional authors for this research include S.A. Rahim and M.A. Joseph.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1088/2053-1591/ab8d5f. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
